dic.name: Chromatic Number
dic.definition: It's the smallest number of colors needed to color the vertices of G so that no two adjacent vertices share the same color
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Chromatic Index (edge)
dic.definition: It's the smallest number of colors needed to color the edges of G so that no two adjacent edges share the same color
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Number of vertices
dic.definition: Number of vertices
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Number of Edges
dic.definition: Number of Edges
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Clique (number and set)
dic.definition: A clique is a subset of nodes in which each pair of nodes is adjacent. The clique number of a graph G is the number of vertices in a maximum clique in G.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the Clique Number button in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can check Clique Number or Maximum Clique Set in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Independence (number and set)
dic.definition: Independent set or stable set is a set of vertices in a graph, no two of which are adjacent. The independence number of a graph G is the number of vertices in a maximum independent set in G.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the Independence Number button in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can check Independence Number or Maximum Independence Set in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Domination (number and set)
dic.definition: A dominating set for a graph G=(V, E) is a subset D of V such that every vertex not in D is adjacent to at least one member of D. The domination number is the number of vertices in a smallest dominating set for G.
dic.usage: For filtering click on 'Domination number' button in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can check 'Domination number' or 'Domination set' in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Total Domination Number
dic.definition: The total domination number of a graph is the size of a smallest total dominating set, where a total dominating set is a set of vertices of the graph such that all vertices (including those in the set itself) have a neighbor in the set. Total dominating numbers are defined only for graphs having no isolated vertex
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Connected Domination Number
dic.definition: The connected domination number of a connected graph G, denoted d(G), is the size of a minimum connected dominating set of a graph G. A connected dominating set in a connected graph G is a dominating set in G whose vertices induce a connected subgraph
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Matching Number
dic.definition: A matching in a graph is a set of edges in which no two distinct edges share a common endpoint. The matching number of graph G, or edge independence number, is the size of a maximum independent edge set.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the Matching Number button in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can check Matching Number or Maximum Matching Set in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Vertex Connectivity
dic.definition: It's the minimum number of nodes that must be removed to disconnect the graph or render it trivial.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Edge Connectivity
dic.definition: It's the minimum number of edges that must be removed to disconnect the graph.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Number of components
dic.definition: It's the number of maximals componnents in the graph
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it..  Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Degree regularity
dic.definition: It's the number of distinct values in the sequence of degrees of the graph.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Maximum Degree
dic.definition: It's the largest vertex degree of G
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Minimum Degree
dic.definition: It's the smallest vertex degree of G
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Average Degree
dic.definition: It's the average degree per vertex in the graph
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Girth
dic.definition: It's the length of a shortest cycle contained in the graph.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Edge Cover
dic.definition: An edge cover of a graph is a set of edges such that every vertex of the graph is incident to at least one edge of the set. The minimum edge cover (set) is an edge covering of smallest cardinality.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use minimum edge cover number. Or in Visualization you can check minimum edge cover number or edge cover in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Vertex Cover Number
dic.definition: It's the size of a minimum vertex cover. A vertex cover (or node cover) of a graph is a set of vertices that includes at least one endpoint of every edge of the graph.
dic.usage: FFor filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Diameter
dic.definition: It's the greatest distance between any pair of vertices.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it. Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Radius
dic.definition: The radius r of a graph is the minimum eccentricity of any vertex. The eccentricity of a vertex is the greatest distance between it and any other vertex.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Adjacency Matrix
dic.definition: It's a square (0,1)-matrix whose elements indicate whether pairs of vertices are adjacent, with the value 1, or not, with the value 0.
dic.usage: In Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Laplacian Matrix
dic.definition: It's L=D-A, where D is the diagonal matrix of node degrees and A is the adjacency matrix of the graph.
dic.usage: In Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Signless Laplacian Matrix
dic.definition: It's L=D+A, where D is the diagonal matrix of node degrees and A is the adjacency matrix of the graph.
dic.usage: In Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Normalized Laplacian Matrix
dic.definition: It's the matrix N=D<sup>½</sup>LD<sup>½</sup>, where L is the Laplacian matrix and D is the diagonal matrix of node degrees.
dic.usage: In Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Incidence Matrix
dic.definition: It's a (0,1)-matrix which has a row for each vertex and column for each edge, and an entry (v,e)=1 iff vertex v is incident upon edge e.
dic.usage: In Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Distance Matrix
dic.definition: It's square matrix containing the distances, taken pairwise, between the vertices.
dic.usage: In Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Largest M-eigenvalue
dic.definition: It's the largest eigenvalue of matrix M.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Algebraic Connectivity
dic.definition: It's the second-smallest eigenvalue (counting multiple eigenvalues separately) of the Laplacian matrix of G. This is L=D-A, where D is the degree matrix and A is the adjacency matrix of the graph.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Energy [matrix M]
dic.definition: Energy of a graph is the sum of the absolute values of the eigenvalues of the M matrix.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Some M-eigenvalue integer
dic.definition: Checks if there is an integer M-eigenvalue, where M is A, L, Q or D.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Spectrum [matrix M]
dic.definition: It's the set of eigenvalues of matrix M
dic.usage: In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Eigenvectors [matrix M]
dic.definition: It is the set of eigenvectors and their eigenvalues in the matrix M
dic.usage: In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: M-integral
dic.definition: Checks if all M-eigenvalues are integer, where M is A, L, Q or D.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Rank of matrix M
dic.definition: This corresponds to the maximal number of linearly independent columns of matrix M, where M is A, L, Q or D.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Invertible matrix M
dic.definition: Check if matrix M is invertible, where M is A, L, Q or D.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Determinant of matrix M
dic.definition: Calculates the determinant of matrix M, where M is A, L, Q or D.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Largest M-eigenvalue is integer
dic.definition: Checks whether the largest M-eigenvalue is an integer, where M is A, L, Q or D.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Main M-eigenvalue (number of)
dic.definition: The eigenvalue x of a matrix M is said to be a main eigenvalue of G, if the eigenspace E(x) is not orthogonal to the all-1 vector. Where M is A, Q or D matrix.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it and get the number of main eigenvalues. Or in Visualization you can check 'number of main M-eigenvalues' or 'main M-eigenvalues (set)' in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Wiener Index
dic.definition: The Wiener index (or the "path number") is a graph index defined for a graph on n nodes by W=½ΣΣ d(i,j), where d(i,j) is the distance between the vertices i and j.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Estrada Index
dic.definition: It's a graph index defined for a graph on n nodes by EE=Σ e<sup>λ</sup>, where λ are the eigenvalues of adjacency matrix.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Nullity
dic.definition: In the matrix theory of graphs, the nullity of the graph is the nullity of the adjacency matrix A of the graph. This nullity equals the multiplicity of the eigenvalue 0 in the spectrum of the adjacency matrix
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Number spanning trees
dic.definition: The number of spanning trees of a connected graph G. A spanning tree T of an undirected graph G is a subgraph that is a tree which includes all of the vertices of G. This invariant can be obtained from Kirchhoff's theorem.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Density
dic.definition: The graph density of simple graphs is defined to be the ratio of the number of edges with respect to the maximum possible edges The density is 0 for a graph without edges and 1 for a complete graph.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it.  Or in Visualization you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph

dic.name: Planar
dic.definition: It's a graph that can be embedded in the plane, i.e., it can be drawn on the plane in such a way that its edges intersect only at their endpoints.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Connected
dic.definition: There is a path from any point to any other point in the graph.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Biconnected
dic.definition: A graph is biconnected if, and only if, it cannot be disconnected by removing only one node (and all edges incident on that node).
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Bipartite
dic.definition: It's a graph whose vertices can be divided into two disjoint and independent sets U and V such that every edge connects a vertex in U to one in V.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Has bridge
dic.definition: A bridge is an edge of a graph whose deletion increases the graph's number of connected components.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Eulerian
dic.definition: It's a graph that has an Eulerian cycle. An Eulerian cycle (Eulerian circuit or Euler tour) in an undirected graph is a cycle that uses each edge exactly once..
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Chordal
dic.definition: It's one in which all induced cycle in the graph should have exactly three vertices.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Triangle-free
dic.definition: It's a graph in which no three vertices form a triangle of edges.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Bull-free
dic.definition: The bull graph is a triangle with two disjoint pendant edges.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Regular graph
dic.definition: It's a graph where each vertex has the same number of neighbors; i.e. every vertex has the same degree
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Cubic graph
dic.definition: It's a regular graph with vertices of degree 3.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Transmission
dic.definition: For each vertex, it calculates the sum of its distances from the other vertices. A graph is Regular Transmission if all sums has the same value.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the Regular Transmission, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can check the Transmission or Regular Transmission in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Self-complementary graph
dic.definition: A self-complementary graph is a graph which is isomorphic to its complement.
dic.usage: For filtering, you can check True (or False) in the respective line, if you want the condition to be satisfied (or not) in the graphs to be filtered. No checks so that filtering does not use this invariant. In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Complement
dic.definition: The complement of a graph G is a graph Comp(G) on the same vertices such that two distinct vertices of c(G) are adjacent if and only if they are not adjacent in G.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it

dic.name: Line graph
dic.definition: The line graph of an undirected graph G is another graph ℓ(G) that represents the adjacencies between edges of G. It's constructed in the following way: for each edge in G, make a vertex in ℓ(G); for every two edges in G that have a vertex in common, make an edge between their corresponding vertices in ℓ(G).
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it

dic.name: Clique graph
dic.definition: Returns the clique graph of the graph. The nodes of the clique graph Ƙ(G) are the maximal cliques of G and an edge joins two cliques if the cliques are not disjoint.
dic.usage: For filtering click on the respective button in the equation to use it

dic.name: Degree Centrality
dic.definition: For each vertex its degree is calculated
dic.usage: In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Eigenvector Centrality
dic.definition: For node i is the i-th element of the normalized eigenvector associated with the largest adjacency eigenvalue
dic.usage: In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Closeness Centrality
dic.definition: For each node is the average length of the shortest path between the node and all other nodes in the graph.
dic.usage: In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Betweenness Centrality
dic.definition: For each nodes computes the number of times the node acts as a bridge along the shortest path between two other nodes.
dic.usage: In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.

dic.name: Harmonic Centrality
dic.definition: For each vertex computes the sum of the inverses of the distances from this vertex to the rest of the graph is calculated.
dic.usage: In Visualization, you can check it in the invariants menu to calculate in the plotted graph.
